COMPLAINT AGAINST THE MEMBER FOR ANSON
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


     Mr Speaker: I would like to inform honourable Members that on 9th October, 1986, I received a complaint from the Leader of the House, under Standing Order 95(7)(c), against the Member for Anson for breach of Parliamentary privilege in respect of five newsletters addressed to the residents of Anson, signed by him, purporting to report on the daily proceedings of the Committee of Privileges meetings from 8th to the 12th of September 1986. ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ARTICLE IN TIME MAGAZINE
(Explanation)


    1. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Prime Minister if he will explain why the statement in an article in Time Magazine for the 8th September 1986 that the government "... introduced a constitutional amendment that, if passed, would deny the right to counsel for an M.P. cited for contempt." is an error of fact as claimed by his Press Secretary.

     The Acting Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am replying on behalf of the Prime Minister.

    The rule that a person who is to be tried by Parliament for contempt has no right to legal represention in Parliament arises from British Parliamentary practice and not from any Singapore constitutional amendment. Section 3(1) of the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act clearly states that the powers, privileges and immunities of Parliament and of the

Column: 752

Speaker, Members and Committees of Parliament shall be the same as those of the Commons House of Parliament of the United Kingdom. In UK, there is no automatic right to counsel for an MP cited for contempt. We follow British practice that Parliament is master of its own procedures.

    The constitutional amendment, referred to by Time, was purely consequential to our importation of the British practice. It was expressly stated in Parliament that the Bill "is exclusively consequential in nature for it makes amendments to the Constitution which are consequential to the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) (Amendment) Act, 1986."

    Time's statement is certainly an error of fact.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question for the Acting Minister. Does the Minister recognize that the statement, to which offence was taken by the Prime Minister's Press Secretary, was a statement in the Time magazine that the Government unexpectedly "introduced a constitutional amendment that, if passed, would deny the right to counsel for an MP cited for contempt."? Is the Minister saying that it is factually wrong that the Government introduced a constitutional amendment? Is that factually wrong?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: We do not have to change the Constitution. The amendment made was the amendment to the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act. There was no constitutional change, just changes to the powers and privileges of Parliament.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: The question, Mr Speaker, Sir, for the Acting Minister, I repeat, is it factually wrong for the Time magazine to have said that the government "introduced a constitutional amendment"? Has the Minister not heard of the Constitution of the Republic of Singapore (Amendment) Bill which was introduced in this House for the first time on the 25th August this year? And does he not accept that it proposed an amendment to the Constitution? May I have an answer to that question?

Column: 753



     Mr Wong Kan Seng: The so-called constitutional amendment was actually the consequential change to the amendment to the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act. It is not unexpected. It is to be expected. It follows the amendment to the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Will the Minister say whether it was the law in Singapore before the introduction of that Bill that a Member of Parliament committed for contempt may not have the right of counsel as provided in the Constitution? Is the Minister saying that that was the law before the Bill was introduced?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the Member for Anson was told of the answer this morning. He was told of this in an answer to the same question that he raised on 22nd September when the amendment was made by the Minister. I suggest that he read the transcript to the Minister's speech when he moved the amendment on the 22nd September. The answers are there.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Will the Minister state then what was factually wrong about that statement? Is he now saying the error was to say it was unexpected? Is that what he is saying? Was that the factual error committed by Time magazine?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: I have already stated, Mr Speaker, Sir, that the amendment was purely consequential to the amendment to the Parliament (Privileges, Immunities and Powers) Act.

     Prof. Jayakumar rose ---

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I have a supplementary question for the Minister again.

     Mr Speaker: On the same point, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: The Minister is going to make some reply. If you will wait for him to reply first.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I see the Minister wants to reply on that.

     The Second Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I step in only

Column: 754

to avoid the House wasting more time. The Acting Minister, not being a lawyer, has given a clear reply. The Member for Anson, being a lawyer, fails to appreciate the point. Now, let us first look what Time magazine said. It said:

    'The government unexpectedly introduced a constitutional amendment that, if passed, would deny the right to counsel for an MP cited for contempt.'

    The impression that this sentence gives is that there had always been a right to counsel in contempt cases in Parliament but this had suddenly been taken away by a constitutional amendment. This is factually and legally not true. The best way of addressing this question, Sir, as the Minister has pointed out, is this. What was the position before the Privileges Act was amended and what was the position after the Privileges Act was amended? Sir, before the Privileges Act was amended, this House always had the power to punish persons cited for contempt. Was there a right to counsel? The position was governed by British practice which we followed, and the British practice as stated in Erskine May is, and I quote:

    'Persons accused of breaches of the privileges or other contempts of either House are not as a rule allowed to be defended by a counsel.'

    So before we amended the Privileges Act, there was no automatic right to counsel. When we amended the Privileges Act recently to incorporate amongst other things the punishment of expulsion, the power of committal, what did we do about the right to counsel? We just maintained the status quo, which is, to continue the practice so that there will be no automatic right to counsel. And the amendment to the Constitution was purely consequential. So there never was an automatic right to counsel. The Privileges Act continued the position and the amendment to the Constitution was consequential.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I hope that puts the matter beyond further dispute.

     Mr Jeyaretnam rose ---

     Mr Speaker: Are you not satisfied yet, Mr Jeyaretnam?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: No, Sir, I am not.

Column: 755



     Mr Speaker: All right. One more supplementary question.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Well, I have two or three more supplementary questions, Mr Speaker, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: You cannot go on forever. One more supplementary question.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am far from satisfied with the answer given by the Minister for Home Affairs and the Second Minister for Law. May I ask the Second Minister for Law this question. If he maintains that the law was never changed by this Bill, and that even before the introduction of the Bill, that Members of Parliament committed for contempt had no right to counsel, may I pray what was the reason for the introduction of that Bill? It seems to me to make nonsense of his answers.

    Secondly, does he realize that the amendment is to an article of the Constitution which does not merely talk about representation or defence. It talks in the first place of consultation, let alone defence. By this amendment the Member of Parliament who is committed has no right even to consult a lawyer, let alone appoint him to appear before any Tribunal of the House. Is that the British practice - that he could not consult any lawyer?

     The Leader of the House (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, on a point of order. The Member is making a speech. He is not asking a question.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Well, I have asked three questions. May I have the answers?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, the debate on the law was conducted and finished on 22nd September. The Member for Anson's question addressed to the Prime Minister and dealt with by the Acting Minister for Community Development was simple: in what way was the Time magazine statement an error of fact? This question has been answered. If he wants now to resurrect the legal argument, it is a separate question which we are fully prepared to defend.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I am asking them now.

     Mr Speaker: All right, second Question. Dr Koh.

Column: 756

RESALE OF HUDC FLATS


    2. Dr Koh Lam Son asked the Minister for National Development, since the announcement by the Housing and Development Board of its decision not to buy back HUDC flats, (a) how many HUDC flat owners have appealed to sell back their flats to HDB and, of these, how many were successful; and (b) how many HUDC flat owners had sold their flats privately and, of these, how many had incurred losses.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the announcement by HDB on 4th July 1986, 49 HUDC lessees appealed to the Board to buy their flats. All were unsuccessful.

    As at 20th September 1986, 27 HUDC flat owners had sold their flats in the open market. Twelve of them sold their flats above their original purchase prices. The remaining 15 owners sold their flats below their origianl purchase prices.

    The Board is unable to tell if these owners had made a profit or incurred a loss. To do so, the Board must take into account imputed rentals and renovation costs which cannot be ascertained accurately.

     Dr Koh Lam Son (Telok Blangah): Supplementary question, Sir. Would the Minister like to consider the following:

    (1) In general, to further relax rules and regulations so that HDB flats can become more competitive.

    (2) In those HUDC estates which are at the moment over-priced, such as the Gillman Heights Estate in the Telok Blangah constituency, would the Minister like to consider adding common facilities, such as squash courts, tennis courts, to enhance the value of the estate?

    (3) In those cases where there is genuine financial hardship, would the Minister consider buying back those flats to help out flat-owners who have a problem selling their flat at short notice because of rules and regulations of the HUDC?

Column: 757



     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, HDB's rules governing HUDC flats, in fact, have been substantially relaxed to allow the HUDC flat-owners to sell their flats within five years of their purchase, and HDB has also waived the levy of 30%. The relaxation of rules has been very substantial, and if the Member for Telok Blangah has any suggestion to further relax the rules, I suggest that he write to me and I will consider it very carefully and sympathetically.

    On this question of additional common facilities when HDB built the HUDC flats, it has provided a set of facilities for each and every HUDC estate, and HDB is prepared to consider reasonable suggestions by the flat-owners to improve the facilities.

    On the question of buying back the flats, it is quite obvious that after the relaxation of the rules, HUDC flat-owners are able to sell their flats in the open market. There is really no compelling need for HDB to buy back the flats.

     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, since the implementation of this policy, how many of the unsold units, or any unit bought by HDB prior to the announcement, have been sold by the Board? If these numbers are small, what steps are being taken by the Board to encourage the purchase of these units? Is the Board considering seriously, in addition to the suggestions made by the Member for Telok Blangah, to improve the existing facilities - I am talking in terms of the Pine Grove HUDC Estate - so as to attract new buyers of these flats?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, since the implementation of the policy, HDB has resold 13 HUDC flats from among those flats HDB bought back from the HUDC owners. In addition, HDB has sold 44 new HUDC flats. The slow sale of HUDC flats is due mainly to the depressed property market. I believe that when the property market recovers in future, more people are expected to buy HUDC flats.

    On the question of additional facilities to be provided in HUDC estates, if the request for the facilities is reasonable and involves a relatively small cost, HDB will consider it.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I be allowed to ask two

Column: 758

supplementary questions? Of the 49 lessees who have been refused permission to sell their flats to the HDB, how many of them have committed themselves to buying private flats? I wonder if the Minister knows how many of them are suffering from hardship because they are committed to buying a private flat since they have been refused permission to sell their HUDC flats back to the HDB.

    If I may ask another question which is related more to HDB flats than to HUDC flats. The Minister will remember that I brought up the point that the HDB has breached its contract by making HDB flat-owners pay more than the agreed price in the agreement of sale and purchase. How many of these 24 flat-owners who have paid in excess of their purchase price have now got their refunds from the HDB?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no figures readily available as to how many of these 49 HUDC flat-owners who requested the Board to buy back the flats have committed themselves to buying other property. I have said earlier that HDB has relaxed the rules to allow HUDC owners to sell their flats in the open market, and those HUDC flat-owners who have committed to buy other flats can sell their HUDC flats in the open market. In fact, many of them have done so.

    On the question of HDB flat-owners who have purchased the HDB flats at a lower price ---

     Mr Chiam See Tong: At the contract price.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: At the contract price or whatever it is, and this is due to the mistake made by the HDB, the HDB has been quite generous. If the mistake made by the HDB staff has been to sell the flat at lower than the posted price, then the owner has the benefit of this mistake. Just for argument's sake, if the flat which should have been sold for $50,000 but because of a mistake the flat had been sold at $45,000, the owner will benefit by the lower price. In other words, he paid $45,000. But if the mistake made by the HDB had been to charge this flat at $55,000, then HDB will refund $5,000 of the additional price paid by the owner. In other words, the HDB flat-owners are having the cake and eating it as well.

Column: 759



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Speaker, the Minister has gone round the mulberry bush but he has not answered my question. Of the 24 purchases at the contract price, how many of them have got their refunds to-date?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, although this question is not relevant, I can assure the Member for Potong Pasir that all of them will get their refund if they have not yet got it. All of them will get their refund.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: When? Ten years from today? I want to know how many of them have got their refunds to-date?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: The Member for Potong Pasir is asking a question which I have to check for an answer. I do not carry with me the millions of accounts of HDB flat-owners with me. So I cannot give him an immediate answer. But I can assure the Member for Potong Pasir that those people will be refunded. If he is asking me for a time limit, certainly it is not 10 years. Perhaps offhand I can say that if they have not already got their money, they should get it within three months.

WORLD TRADE CENTRE CAR PARKS
(Free parking on Sundays and Public holidays)


    5. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon: To ask the Minister for Communications and Information whether the Port of Singapore Authority, following the example of the Housing and Development Board, will implement the free parking scheme on Sundays and public holidays for the World Trade Centre car parks.

     Mr Speaker: Mrs Yu-Foo.

     Mr Goh Chee Wee (Boon Lay): Question No. 5, Sir.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the free parking scheme on Sundays and public holidays implemented at some of the HDB car parks seeks to encourage social visits among family members and friends. This scheme was implemented at the request of residents of the estates concerned.

    The rationale is not applicable to the car parks at the World Trade Centre which do not serve housing estates. These car parks are meant to serve the patrons of shops, restaurants, offices, exhibition halls, conferences, and other shows held at the Centre.

     Dr Koh Lam Son: Sir, is the Minister aware that there are, in fact, other HDB car parks in non-residential areas, such as industrial estates and hospital car parks, which are enjoying the free car parking scheme? I also do not agree with the Minister and would like to ask him whether he would agree with my view that, in fact, quite a number of people who make use of the HDB car parks at the World Trade Centre are people who go to Sentosa Island during the week-ends and this involves family members and friends.

Column: 761



     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member would have noted that in Singapore there is no rush among the shop owners and hawkers close to car parks asking the HDB to allow free parking on Sundays. The reason is very obvious. People who patronize the shops, the hawker centres, etc. do not park there for long periods of time. If there were to be large numbers of people parking their cars free for a long period of time in such car parks, it is not improbable that the livelihood of shopowners and hawkers may be affected.

Column: 761

ANSON PEOPLE'S ASSEMBLY
(Delay in registration)


    6. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether there is any reason why the Registrar of Societies should delay the registration of the proposed Anson People's Assembly.

     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, it is not the Registrar of Societies who has delayed the registration of the proposed Anson People's Assembly. As the Registrar informed the Member for Anson on 11th September, 1986, the delay in registration is, and here I quote, Sir:

    "caused by repeated non-compliance of requirements and incomplete submission of details and information on your part."

    When the Member for Anson first applied on 9th October, 1985, for registration of the society, the Registrar of Societies found its constitution incomplete and contrary to the standard requirements of a non-political society. Among other things, it did not include the standard prohibition clauses against indulging in political activities and allowing its funds or premises to be used for political purposes. Details such as the procedure for election of office bearers were omitted. As the main objective of the proposed society was to promote the welfare of the residents and membership was restricted to residents of the Anson Constituency, the Member for Anson was also requested to appoint a resident of Anson as the Secretary of the society.

Column: 762



    In his reply in July 1986, the Member for Anson did agree to appoint a resident of Anson as Secretary, but he failed to name the Secretary. Moreover, his revised constitution still did not include the prohibition clauses on political activities for a non-political society.

    Sir, in his latest reply of 6th October 1986, the Member for Anson has now said that some of the society's, and here I quote "activities may be considered political." As such, he has refused to include the prohibition clauses on political activities. So long as the Memberfor Anson persists in not complying with the requirements of the Registrar of Societies, it will not be possible for the application to be approved.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Supplementary questions for the Minister of State. Does the Minister appreciate that the Registrar took more than two months to reply to my letter of the 8th July 1986? And does he also appreciate that this has been the pattern of the Registrar's letters replying to our letters even before that --- that he has taken two to three months to give answers to questions posed by us?

    Secondly, will the Minister state whether the proposed Assembly has declared its intention to have any premises? So does he accept that the requirement that the premises be not used for any political purposes is a non sequitur because there are no premises for this Assembly? Will the Minister state why is the Registrar making a fuss about premises when there is no intention to have any premises?

    Thirdly, will the Minister of State read the whole of my letter of the 6th October in regard to the Registrar's query whether any of the activities may be political? Does he not think it is only fair that he should read the whole of my letter?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Anson takes objection to the two-month interval between his letter to the Registrar of Societies and the reply. He should know that the Registrar of Societies deals with thousands of societies in Singapore and it is the Registrar's duty to deal with every query expeditiously. Queries bearing sufficient information will certainly be dealt with in a much shorter time.
